resolvedstellarpops.io package¶

Submodules¶

resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO module¶

class resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.InputFile(filename, default_dict=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

a class to replace too many kwargs from the input file. does two things: 1. sets a default dictionary (see input_defaults) as attributes 2. unpacks the dictionary from load_input as attributes

(overwrites defaults).

Methods

set_defaults(in_def)[source]¶
unpack_dict(udict=None)[source]¶
class resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.InputFile2(filename, default_dict=None)[source]¶

Bases: dict

a class to replace too many kwargs from the input file. does two things: 1. sets a default dictionary (see input_defaults) as attributes 2. unpacks the dictionary from load_input as attributes

(overwrites defaults).

Methods

class resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.InputParameters(default_dict=None)[source]¶

Bases: dict

need to make a dictionary of all the possible parameters
(in the ex: rsp.TrilegalUtils.galaxy_input_dict())
need to make a formatted string with dictionary printing
(in the ex: rsp.TrilegalUtils.galaxy_input_fmt())

example import ResolvedStellarPops as rsp inp = rsp.fileIO.input_parameters(default_dict=rsp.TrilegalUtils.galaxy_input_dict()) send any replacement params as kwargs. inp.write_params(‘test’, rsp.TrilegalUtils.galaxy_input_fmt()) $ cat test

use print inp to see what current values are in cmd line.

Methods

add_params(new_dict)[source]¶

add or overwrite attributes from dictionary

possible_params(default_dict={})[source]¶

assign key as attribute name and value as attribute value from dictionary

update_params(new_dict)[source]¶

only overwrite attributes that already exist from dictionary

write_params(new_file, formatter)[source]¶

get_col(key)[source]¶

resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.ensure_dir(f)[source]¶

will make all dirs necessary for input to be an existing directory. if input does not end with ‘/’ it will add it, and then make a directory.

resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.ensure_file(f, mad=True)[source]¶

input f (string): if f is not a file will print “no file” optional mad (bool)[True]: if mad is True, will exit program.

resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.get_files(src, search_string)[source]¶

returns a list of files, similar to ls src/search_string

resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.get_row(arr, index_key, index)[source]¶

send a np.array with dtype.names and choose a column item. For example: $ data.dtype.names (‘target’, ‘opt_trgb’, ‘nopt_trgb’, ‘nopt_agb’, ‘ir_trgb’, ‘nir_trgb’, ‘nir_agb’) # for an array like: (‘kkh37’, 23.54, 2561.0, 147.0, 21.96, 1729.0, 151.0), get_row(data, ‘target’, ‘kkh37’) (‘kkh37’, 23.54, 2561.0, 147.0, 21.96, 1729.0, 151.0)

resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.item_from_row(arr, index_key, index, column_name)[source]¶

send a np.array with dtype.names and choose a column item. For example: $ data.dtype.names (‘target’, ‘opt_trgb’, ‘nopt_trgb’, ‘nopt_agb’, ‘ir_trgb’, ‘nir_trgb’, ‘nir_agb’) # for an array like: (‘kkh37’, 23.54, 2561.0, 147.0, 21.96, 1729.0, 151.0), $ item_from_row(data, ‘target’, ‘kkh37’, ‘opt_trgb’) 23.54

resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.load_input(filename)[source]¶

reads an input file into a dictionary. file must have key first then value(s) Will make ‘True’ into a boolean True Will understand if a value is a float, string, or list, etc. Ignores all lines that start with #, but not with # on the same line as key, value.

resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.read_table(filename, comment_char='#', loud=False)[source]¶
resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.read_tagged_phot(tagged_file)[source]¶

reads an ascii photometry file that has been tagged by stage.

resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.readfile(filename, col_key_line=0, comment_char='#', string_column=None)[source]¶

reads a file as a np array, uses the comment char and col_key_line to get the name of the columns.

resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.replace_ext(filename, ext)[source]¶

input filename string with .ext new_ext replace ext with new ext eg: $ replace_ext(‘data.02.SSS.v4.dat’, ‘.log’) data.02.SSS.v4.log

resolvedstellarpops.io.fileIO.savetxt(filename, data, fmt='%.4f', header=None)[source]¶

np.savetxt wrapper that adds header. Some versions of savetxt already allow this...
